citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the Program of Veterinary Care, contingency plan, record of animals on hand, environmental
enhancement program for non-human primates, and records of acquisition and disposition were not available for review
by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the
inspector to determine compliance of documents and evaluate animal welfare. The licensee must, during business hours,
allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations. Correction
date: April 13, 2023.

There were two guinea pig enclosures with an excessive accumulation of feces and wet/soiled bedding. Ineffective
cleaning and sanitation expose the animals to disease hazards and health problems. Primary enclosures must be cleaned
often enough to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, excreta, and soiled bedding. They must also be sanitized at least
once every 2 weeks in an approved manner. Correct by March 24, 2023.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with a facility representative.
End Section

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the Program of Veterinary Care, contingency plan, record of animals on hand, environmental 
enhancement program for non-human primates, and records of acquisition and disposition were not available for review 
by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the 
inspector to determine compliance of documents and evaluate animal welfare. The licensee must, during business hours, 
allow APHIS officials to examine records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations. Correction 
date: April 13, 2023. 
3.31(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
There were two guinea pig enclosures with an excessive accumulation of feces and wet/soiled bedding. Ineffective 
cleaning and sanitation expose the animals to disease hazards and health problems. Primary enclosures must be cleaned 
often enough to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, excreta, and soiled bedding. They must also be sanitized at least 
once every 2 weeks in an approved manner. Correct by March 24, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with a facility representative.

End Section

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
